body.p: Which of the following is not considered to be a part of the upper respiratory tract?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The paranasal sinuses are located in the nasal cavity of the nose which is located in the upper respiratory tract.
Incorrect. The adenoids are located in the nasopharynx which is the most superior portion of the pharynx. Which is part of the the upper respiratory tract.
Incorrect. The epiglottis is located superiorly to the trachea and prevents food from entering the airway. Which is part of the the upper respiratory tract.
Correct. The alveoli are located at the ends of the terminal bronchial tubes in the lungs and are part of the lower respiratory tract.

body.p: Which of the following structures contains membranes with mucus glands and blood vessels to help humidify and warm air?

feedback.p: Correct. The conchae increase the surface area of the nasal cavity and are responsible for helping to warm and humidify the incoming air.
Incorrect. The auditory tube functions to equilibrate the air pressure between the environment and middle ear.
Incorrect. The epiglottis is composed of cartilage that allows it to prevent food from entering the trachea.
Incorrect. The trachea is composed of three layers: the mucosa, submucosa and adventitia. The three layers allow for production and movement mucus.

body.p: If there was a blockage in a terminal bronchiole a person would not be able to breath at all.

feedback.p: Incorrect. A blockage of the terminal bronchiole would impair a person’s ability to breath but the terminal bronchioles are the smallest branch of the bronchial tree and would not prevent a person from breathing at all.

Correct. A blockage of the terminal bronchiole would cause some impairment because the alveolar sac attached to that terminal bronchiole would not be able to inflate, but it would not completely block the person’s ability to breath.

body.p: Which of the following is not considered to be a part of the conducting zone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The nose is where air will enter the body but not be absorbed.
Incorrect. The pharynx is part of the system of tubes that connects the mouth to the lungs.
Incorrect. The trachea or windpipe is part of the conducting system but it does not participate in the exchange of gases.
Correct. The alveoli are part of the respiratory zone because this is where the exchange of gases occurs.

body.p: Smoking causes the paralysis and destruction of the ciliate cells of the conducting zone. What is a possible result of this?

input.choice: The air will not reach the appropriate level of humidity and will damage the thin-walled alveoli.
The hairs of the nose will not be able to trap large particles.
The mixture of mucus and particles will not be moved to the esophagus to be swallowed.
The carbonic anhydrase will not be able to function properly.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The humidity is provided by the membranes of the nose and mouth.
Incorrect. The hairs of the nose are not the same as cilia which are hair like projections of cells. The hair will still act as a physical barrier.

Correct. With the cilia paralyzed or destroyed the mucociliary elevator will not work properly and the mucus will not move out of the lungs to the esophagus. This results in the classic “smoker’s cough.”
Incorrect. The carbonic anhydrase is affected if the temperature of the incoming air is too cold.

body.p: Pulmonary ventilation involves which of the following processes?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Expiration or exhalation is half of pulmonary ventilation where air is exiting the body.
Incorrect. Inspiration or inhalation is half of the pulmonary ventilation where air is entering the body.
Incorrect. Cellular respiration occurs in the cell where oxygen is used to convert nutrients into cellular energy.
Correct. Pulmonary ventilation is the process of exchanging air with the atmosphere. This process includes both expiration and inspiration.

body.p: If a person travels to Denver, CO they may feel short of breath until their body adjusts because:

input.choice: The percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere is lower.
The percentage of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is higher

feedback.p: Incorrect. The percentage of oxygen is the same as you change altitudes

Correct. The atmospheric pressure is lower at higher altitudes which means the difference between the atmospheric pressure and the alveolar pressure is less. This makes it harder to move air into and out of the body.
Incorrect. The percentage of carbon dioxide is the same as you change altitudes.

Incorrect. Boyle’s law describes the relationship between volume and pressure. For example as the thoracic cavity increases in volume it decreases in pressure. It does not explain why a person feels short of breath.

body.p: Referring to the picture above, answer the following two questions.
As the rib cage moves out and the diagram moves down the volume of the thoracic cavity and the pressure in the thoracic cavity.

feedback.p: Correct. The volume will increase as the muscles contract and pull the ribs out and the diaphragm down.
Incorrect. As the muscles of the ribs and the diaphragm contract they will shorten, pulling the ribs out and the diaphragm down.
Incorrect. Volume and pressure have inverse relationships, so in order for the pressure to increase the volume would have to decrease and this would result in air moving out of the lungs.
Correct. Volume and pressure have inverse relationships, so as the volume increases the pressure decreases. This results in air moving into the lungs.

body.p: Air will be moving into the body in this diagram.

feedback.p: Correct. As the volume of the thoracic cavity increases, the pressure decreases. This results in air flowing from the area of higher pressure outside the body to the area of lower pressure inside the body.
Incorrect. As the volume of the thoracic cavity increase the pressure will decrease. As the pressure decreases the air can move into the body.

body.p: Compliance of the lungs depends on what two characteristics?

input.choice: Elasticity of the connective tissue and bronchiolar constriction
Elasticity of the connective tissue and alveolar surface tension
Elasticity of the connective tissue and bronchiolar dilatation
Alveolar surface tension and bronchiolar dilatation

feedback.p: Incorrect. The elasticity of the connective tissue of the lungs will affect the compliance of the lungs, but bronchiolar constriction will increase the resistance of the lungs not the compliance.

Correct. The compliance of the lungs explains the relationship between the pressure and volume change in the ease of breathing and is affected by the elasticity of the connective tissue and the alveolar surface tension.
Incorrect. The elasticity of the connective tissue of the lungs will affect the compliance of the lungs, but bronchiolar dilatation will decrease the resistance of the lungs not the compliance.
Incorrect. The surface tension of the alveoli will affect the compliance of the lungs, but bronchiolar dilatation will increase the resistance of the lungs not the compliance.

body.p: Which of the following is not evaluated through the process of spirometry?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Lung volumes such as the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume and expiratory reserve volume are frequently measured with spirometry.
Correct. Dead space is measured using a nitrogen washout or Folwer’s method test.
Incorrect. Lung capacities are combinations of lung volumes such as the vital capacity which is the TV+ IRV+ ERV
Incorrect. The flow rate is measured using a spirometer and used to help diagnose obstructive and restrictive disorders.

body.p: Which of the following would not be increased by an olympic swimmer training to hold their breath for a long period of time?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The inspiratory capacity is equal to the sum of the TV and the IRV. An olympic swimmer will train to be able to breath in more and increase this capacity.
Incorrect. The inspiratory reserve volume will increase as a the swimmer trains be be able to inhale more air as they hold their breath.
Correct. The residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after the ERV has been expelled. The residual volume will remain in the lungs even after death.
Incorrect. The vital capacity is the TV+ IRV+ERV. As the IRV increases so will the viatal capacity.

body.p: Which of the following is an example of an obstructive lung disorder?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Tuberculosis will lower the compliance of the lungs and by changing the lung tissue so is a restrictive disorder.
Incorrect. Fibrosis will lower the compliance of the lungs and by changing the lung tissue so is a restrictive disorder.
Incorrect. Muscular dystrophy will impeded the normal muscular function and lower the ability of the chest wall to constrict and relax normally so is a restrictive disorder.
Correct. Asthma will increase the resistance of the lungs to airflow and increase the amount of time it takes for air to enter and exit the lungs.
